div.p: ANTONIO: So, to bring this back to alcohol and drugs... If I have a high tolerance, I may feel like it's protecting me from having problems.
ANTONIO: But in reality, a high tolerance can make me less sensitive to the effects of alcohol, and lead me to believe I'm not at risk for problems, when I am.
ANTONIO: A person with low tolerance feels the effect and stops. A person with high tolerance does not feel it for a long time and keeps on drinking.
ANTONIO: By the time they realize they are impaired, it is often too late to protect themselves.
ONLINE USER 1: I've always been proud of the fact that I had a high tolerance. I used to brag to everyone that I may be small but I can hold my liquor.

ONLINE USER 2: Well, I have a low tolerance and I'm actually the one who's falling asleep on the couch after a few beers. But, a lot of my friends are able to drink a lot more than me and have a high tolerance.
ONLINE USER 2: It's pretty scary, because they're the ones I'm going to at the end of the night to drive me home.
ONLINE USER 3: Well, you can't change your biology... I've always had a high tolerance.
ANTONIO: Yeah, okay... it's understandable we might still believe having a high tolerance helps us, especially if we haven't experienced problems yet.
ANTONIO: But let's take a closer look at the pattern of how a high-tolerance can trick us into believing we're not at risk for impairment problems.
